data.Description: Common name for categories of cover crops
Family common name
data.Values: [Grass family, Nonlegumes, Legumes, Mustard family, Aster family, Pea family, Buckwheat family, Flax family, Borage family]

data.Description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES
data.Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

data.Description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES
data.Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

data.Description: Ability to tolerate heat relative to other species
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES
data.Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

data.Description: Likelihood of cover crop survival over the winter.
data.Team Notes: Can we indicate winter kill temp for diff maturity? or comments?

data.Description: Ability to tolerate high salinity relative to other species. Scale 1-5
data.Team Notes: [Low = tolerant to 2.1-4.0 dS/m; Medium = tolerant to 4.1-8.0 dS/m; High = tolerant to greater than 8.0 dS/m.]
data.Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

data.Description: Ability to tolerate poor fertility in general (an amalgamation of low pH soils and/or below-optimum soil tests for N, P, and/or K, sandy soil)
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES
data.Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

data.Description: Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES
data.Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

data.Description: Growth form or predominant shape of an individual plant.
Hessian Fly-Free Date, after which wheat and other plants can be planted to avoid cereal rust.

Amount of dry biomass the cover crop produces in a year, lbs/A.

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: improve soil organic matter, lasting residue, prevent soil eriosion, promote water quality, nitrogen fixation, nitrogen scavanging, and weed suppression.
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES. Proposed Baseline: [0<Low<1000, 1000<Med<3000, High>3000]

data.Description: Some plants have different Durations depending on environment or location, so a plant can have more than one value. Multiple values are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.
Season in which plants have active growth.

Amount of N a legume species contains, lbs/A. This is combined nitrogen fixed plus nitrogen taken up from the soil.

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: nitrogen source
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES. Proposed Baseline: [0<Low<50; 50<Med<100; High>100]

data.Description:
C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower at the vegetative state then at the flowering state.

1 to 5 rating. General guide for cover crops at flowering, but there are exceptions:
1 - Legumes
2 - Succulent broadleafs
3 - Woodier broadleafs (sunflowers, annual rye grass)
4 - Cereal grains
5 - Warm season annuals


Impacts following goals: Improve soil organic matter, lasting residue, prevent soil erosion, weed suppression
data.Team Notes: Team must define the values, range, and options. Proposed Baseline: [0<Low<12; 12<Medium<20; High>20]
data.Values: 1 - Legumes, 2 - Succulent broadleafs, 3 - Woodier broadleafs (sunflowers, annual rye grass), 4 - Cereal grains, 5 - Warm season annuals

data.Description: Is it commonly used in the zone or only beginning to gain adoption?

Amount of dry biomass the cover crop produces in a year, lbs/A.

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: improve soil organic matter, lasting residue, prevent soil eriosion, promote water quality, nitrogen fixation, nitrogen scavanging, and weed suppression.
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES. Proposed Baseline: [0<Low<1000, 1000<Med<3000, High>3000]

data.Description:
Amount of N a legume species contains, lbs/A. This is combined nitrogen fixed plus nitrogen taken up from the soil.

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: nitrogen source
data.Team Notes: Each team must define the "low medium high" VALUES. Proposed Baseline: [0<Low<50; 50<Med<100; High>100]

data.Description: Level of soil drainage needed for acceptable cover crop growth given regular rainfall.
data.Values: [Very poorly drained, Poorly drained, Somewhat poorly drained, Moderately well drained, Well drained, Excessively drained, Saturated muck, Well drained muck]

data.Description: Ability to establish and grow in soil with coarse, medium, and fine textured soils given regular rainfall.
The minimum soil pH, of the top 12 inches of soil, within the plant’s known geographical range.
The maximum soil pH, of the top 12 inches of soil, within the plant’s known geographical range.
Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.
Cover crop survival under flooding/ponding conditions

Relative ability of cover crop to loosen topsoil (0 to 6 inches).

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: reduces topsoil compaction

Relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.

Impacts the following goals: Increase soil aggregation, promote water quality

Relative ability of cover crop to break up subsurface soil compaction (6 to 12 inches). Including management induced compaction.

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: reduces subsurface soil compaction
Type of inoculant that needs to applied to legume seed to promote N fixation
data.Values: [none, alfalfa, berseem clover, cowpea, crimson clover, lespedeza, lima bean, pea/vetch, pea/vetch/lentil, peanut, red clover, soybean, sweetclover, white clover]

data.Description: Details about when flowering occurs, triggers for flowering
data.Values: [Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size]

data.Description: Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

How deeply rooted is this cover crop? Consider the relative ability of the roots to go deeper the previous crop was (where residual nitrogen lies).

Impacts the following goals: Promote water quality, reduces topsoil compaction, nitrogen scavenging

Speed at which the cover crop establishes once planted.
1 - slow to establish
5 - quick to establish

What is the primary root structure: tap or fibrous?

Impacts the following goals:  Increase soil aggregation, prevent soil erosion, proote water quality, reduces subsurface soil compaction, reduces topsoil compaction

Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be suitable for growing and terminating during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.
data.Values: [Very Short, Short, Medium, Long, Very Long]

data.Description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish
Minimum temperature required for cover crop seed to germinate within 5 days.
Average number of cover crop seeds in a pound of seed
Depth to plant seed in fractions of an inch
data.Units/Details: inches, down to quarter, half, and eigths

data.Description: Cover crop can be seeded when ground is frozen.
Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, 3 stars is most expensive. Rating is relative.
data.Team Notes: Each team should recommend a data source for pricing, e.g. green cover crop seed

data.Description: Can aerial seeding methods be used for this crop?

The base seeding rate (PLS) represents optimal planting time, optimal termination time, optimal planting method (drilled/cultivate and cultipack), conventional tillage method, no planting green, and no interseeding in a monoculture context. Lower limit (min) is approx 30% ground coverage.

The base seeding rate (PLS)  represents optimal planting time, optimal termination time, optimal planting method (drilled/cultivate and cultipack), conventional tillage method, no planting green, and no interseeding in a monoculture context. Upper limit (Max) is for intensive activity such as weed suppression or forage.
Depth to plant seed in fractions of an inch
data.Units/Details: inches, down to quarter, half, and eigths

data.Description:
Likelihood that tillage (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that disturb the soil, as with disking or rotovating) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage. The expert group premises that all cover crops can be terminated with tillage, but that 1 represents hard to terminate with tillage and requires an aggressive technique, where as 5 is easy to terminate with tillage and requires the least aggressive technique. The techniques are categoriezed as follows.

5-light disk
4-heavy disk
3-chisel plow
2-rototill
1-moldboard
Likelihood that conditions below 32 degrees F will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
data.Values: 5. Likely to terminate in mild freeze 1. Requires a very significant freeze to terminate

data.Description: Likelihood that herbicide application will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.

Likelihood that tillage (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that disturb the soil, as with disking or rotovating) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage. The expert group premises that all cover crops can be terminated with tillage, but that 1 represents hard to terminate with tillage and requires an aggressive technique, where as 5 is easy to terminate with tillage and requires the least aggressive technique. The techniques are categoriezed as follows.

5-light disk
4-heavy disk
3-chisel plow
2-rototill
1-moldboard
Likelihood that conditions below 32 degrees F will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.
data.Values: 5 likely to terminate in mild freeze  1 requires a very significant freeze to terminate

data.Description: Likelihood that herbicide application will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Likelihood that mowing (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that do not disturb the soil) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.

Likelihood that roller-crimping will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage. Termination is most successful at higher crop densities (3+ tons of drymatter per acre).

Roller crimping is usually used in tandem with chemical termination outside of organic systems.
Extent to which the cover crop can serve as habitat for pollinators.
Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

Risk of previous cover crop volunteering in current cash crop due to management (i.e. the previous cover crop setting seed that became part of the soil weed seedbank). 1=rarely volunteers, 5=frequently volunteers
Shorter-term issue, relies more on management. May be positive if you want it to re-seed. Impact depends on crop rotation.

Indicator of likelihood that the cover crop seed, once planted, will sit in the soil for an extended time then germinate at an inopportune moment (e.g., during cash crop growth). 1= rarely has hard seed, 5=hard seed is a frequent concern. 
"Hardseedness" in MW tool "Risk is in the CC seedbag", long-term issue.
Ability of a cover crop to decrease nematode populations (e.g., trap crop). 1=poor choice for discouraging nematodes, 5=excellent choice

Ability of a cover crop to increase nematode populations. 
1=does not support nematode populations, 5=excellent for increasing nematode populations
Ability of a cover crop to decrease insect pest populations. 1=poor choice for discouraging insect pests, 5=excellent choice
Ability of a cover crop to increase insect pest populations. 1=does not promote insect populations, 5=frequently promotes pest insects

Relative ranking of cover crop's impact in suppressing disease in the following cash crop. 
1 - does not suppress disease in following cash crop.
5 - very likely to suppress disease in following cash crop.

Relative ranking of cover crop's impact on promoting disease in the following cash crop. 
1 - does not promote disease in following cash crop.
5 - very likely to promote disease in following cash crop.
